description:
Pygathrix nemaeus, commonly known as the gray-shanked douc, is a species of Old World monkey endemic to a small region in central Vietnam. It belongs to the Cercopithecidae family and the Colobinae subfamily.

The gray-shanked douc is a medium-sized primate, with a body length of around 50-65 cm and a weight ranging from 10-15 kg. It has a distinctive appearance, with a gray body, bright red face, and striking white, black, and orange markings on its limbs and tail. The species is arboreal, spending most of its time in the upper canopy of tropical evergreen forests.

Gray-shanked doucs are primarily folivorous, feeding on a variety of leaves, fruits, and flowers. They live in multi-male, multi-female social groups and exhibit complex social behaviors, including vocalizations, grooming, and play. The species is considered Critically Endangered due to habitat loss, hunting, and the illegal wildlife trade.

Conservation efforts, including the establishment of protected areas and anti-poaching measures, are ongoing to protect this unique and threatened primate species.
